extObjects
Returns the object collection of the selected GreenData app that provided access to data.
To use the function, a connection to the external application must be configured. For more details, see the article "
Integration between platform applications
".
Syntax
extObjects
(connectObj, typeIdObj, attr)
Parameter
Purpose
connectObj
Object containing the settings for the connection to the external application.
The value must be an instance of the "External Application Connection" [SYS_CONNECTION_EXT] object type.
For more details on creating a connection, refer to the article "
Integration between platform applications
".
typeIdObj
Object type from the external application whose collection of objects needs to be retrieved.
attr
Selecting of an attribute of the specified object type, the value of which needs to be retrieved or modified.
Note
The function is called from the
"Sources"
tab of the algorithm editor toolbar, resulting in a modal window opening for parameter selection.
Selecting the object type and its attributes becomes available after choosing the object with settings for the connection to the external application.
Use examples
Example 1
For example the goal is to configure the ability to manage product pricing in
Application B
from
Application A
.
In
Application B
, a custom token is created in the user card of a user with permission to edit instances of the "Catalog" type. This token will be used in
Application A
when creating the connection to the
external application
.
Assume that for a sale, the price for all items in the "Catalog" type needs to be set to "999".
For this action, it is not necessary to have synchronized object types with the same UUID.
An algorithm created in
Application A
can take the following form:
See more
var
for defining a variable;
forEach
for implementing a loop through the collection of "Catalog" type objects;
attrByVar
for changing the price of items;
save
for saving the changed object in the
application B
.
As a result of the algorithm’s execution, the prices of all objects in the "Catalog" object type of
Application B
will be changed:
Example 2
However, if within the simplified integration, the values of a specific product need to be changed, for example, items named "T-shirt," the algorithm will be as follows:
Unlike Example 1, this algorithm uses the
filterAlg
function to configure filtering by the "Name" attribute.
When using a filtering algorithm based on attributes of the parent type "Object" (Name, ID, Create date, etc.), synchronization of object type data is not required.
When using a filtering algorithm based on non-parent type attributes, the extObjects function allows accessing the attribute values of the external application’s object type only if the object type data is synchronized (the object types must have identical UUIDs).
As a result of the algorithm’s execution, in the "Catalog" object type of
Application B
, only the prices of instances named "T-shirt" will be changed:
